typically most people default to thinking about virtual machines and virtual machines are great because we
have a highly configurable environment if you look at it on the left hand side it's something where you can customize
it to your needs you can set up your images based on whatever software you need and you can set up sort of
sandboxing and networking between those virtual machines with the cloud platform
we also have a feature called the cloud marketplace where you can get predetermined solutions that other
people have configured pre-configured at VMs so that you can get straightaway a web server with some with the database
VM pre-configured and configure and set up to talk to each other but what are
the downsides to VMs is that they're heavy right when you think about a virtual machine you're kind of emulating
the whole environment you're in emulating a sea you memory graphic stack Network stack
disks and so on and there may be some of you in the room that say uh VMs aren't exactly emulation you're right we're not
on x86 we're not necessarily emulating x86 architecture but just for the sake
of brevity here you can think of it like emulation we're treating it like a whole machine so as you start to have more and
more VMs you tend to sort of give away some resources to managing to running
multiple VMs now if you're using a cloud it doesn't matter whether it's Google Microsoft or Amazon it doesn't really
matter how many VMs you have you pay a certain cost for those but wouldn't it be great if we could get the sort of
same benefits that we tend to have with VMs and sandboxing but in a lighter way well docker solved that for us with
containers right and docker containers have now become a standard format for all of us to to ship software well not
for all of us I think it's it's certainly very popular right now not everybody's doing it yet but I expect
that more and more we're gonna start to see people deploying containers on cloud now with the Google cloud platform
there's basically two ways that you can deploy your containers one is through our product called kubernetes engine and
another is through Google App Engine kubernetes engine is is basically our managed kubernetes service so if you've
not heard of kubernetes before it's an open source platform for that basically
allows you to treat your applications as applications not as a machine you can kind of start to disassociate the
infrastructure side of things and what happened is that for over a decade
Google has been running its services on an internal product called Borg which
basically were the same concept of containers and we've been doing that for a long time even for our internal builds
as well as for our actual products and bhaag allowed us to because we'd containerized all of our our services it
allowed us to scale up and down based on user requests user needs and it would do it automatically so what we decided to
do was take although these sort of internal bits and pieces and turn it into a full-blown open-source product
that we called kubernetes and we launched kubernetes four years ago maybe a little bit more
than four years ago and it's adoption has really taken off to the point now where you have managed kubernetes
services provided by all the big cloud providers Google included now Google
actually whoops I'll get to that in a second Google's managed kubernetes services
called google kubernetes engine and if you want to know what the difference between sort of kubernetes and docker is
you can think of docker as a container format kubernetes actually goes and
orchestrates multiple containers so imagine you've got a bunch of containers that need to come up and the dependencies between your clusters of
containers kubernetes makes it easy for you to be able to handle those dependencies you can have a load
balancer a bunch of web front-ends maybe a few database instances and so on and you can set those to auto scale now
remember I said there's kubernetes engine which is that managed service I also said that there's App Engine App
Engine flex in particular is a way for you to again host kubernetes sorry
docker containers but where this time you don't need to go into the finer details that you do with kubernetes with
kubernetes you you have very explicit controls about how you want to scale your application with App Engine given
any a container image and just let it scale for you that's the promise of App Engine flex we also have this a
different version of App Engine called standard and that's a much more tighter sandbox environment with very specific
versions of languages that we support we're not going to talk about that today in fact the application that we are
using today is running on App Engine flex but the reason that I wanted to
show you what kubernetes engine was is because the source code when you download it you can choose whether you
want to post it on google kubernetes engine or on App Engine they are interchangeable for this particular demo
that we're doing so going back to our diagram here we've got our like highly
customizable world here we've got our container world here when we look at something like building container images
we also offer a product called cloud build which can integrate with your source control systems so that you can
kick off a build and generate a container image once that build is complete it can then pop that container image to a container
registry which by the way can be private to you it doesn't mean it has to be public and then once you've you've got
your container images in your container registry you can deploy them to whichever other services that you want
you can do rolling updates and so on now in this new world that we're starting to
get towards we started we've probably heard of the term server list we now have a product called cloud functions and with cloud functions you
can write bite-sized pieces of code think of them as components of your application and they will be triggered
when specific events are fired and you declare those events so an example of something that you might want to do is
if you have a product that has users uploading user-generated content let's
say you have images that users are uploading when a new image is uploaded to your storage bucket you might want to
go and generate thumbnails of different sizes for those images so that when you serve them to your users
it's those thumbnails are pre generated that's a great use case for for a cloud function now if we turn this diagram
around a little bit you can think of cloud functions being the the most managed version of all of this
as a service platform for event based micro services App Engine will as I said
you just give it your container image will will scale it for you with kubernetes kubernetes engine we give you

there is a lot more responsibility on the developer or on the DevOps folks because you need to make sure that the
versions of the operating system that you're running here or any supporting services are running the latest versions
from a security standpoint right you need to make sure you're the one that's sort of tracking those patches and so on
